review.title: A Method for Image Reduction Based on a Generalization of Ordered Weighted Averaging Functions
review.abstract: In this paper we propose a special type of aggregation function which generalizes the notion of Ordered Weighted Averaging Function - OWA. The resulting functions are called Dynamic Ordered Weighted Averaging Functions --- DYOWAs. This generalization will be developed in such way that the weight vectors are variables depending on the input vector. Particularly, this operators generalize the aggregation functions: Minimum, Maximum, Arithmetic Mean, Median, etc, which are extensively used in image processing. In this field of research two problems are considered: The determination of methods to reduce images and the construction of techniques which provide noise reduction. The operators described here are able to be used in both cases. In terms of image reduction we apply the methodology provided by Patermain et al. We use the noise reduction operators obtained here to treat the images obtained in the first part of the paper, thus obtaining images with better quality.

metadata.title: A Method for Image Reduction Based on a Generalization of Ordered Weighted Averaging Functions∗

sections.text: In this paper, we propose a special type of aggregation function that generalizes the term Ordered Weighted Averaging Function - OWA. The resulting functions are called Dynamic Ordered Averaging Functions - DYOWAs. This generalization is developed so that the weight vectors are variables depending on the input vector. In particular, these operators generalize the aggregation functions: minimum, maximum, arithmetic mean, median, etc., which are widely used in image processing. In this research area, two problems are considered: the determination of image reduction methods and the preprint transactions on fuzzy systems submitted to IEEE. † Federal University of Semi-Arid - UFERSA, Pau dos Ferros, RN, Brazil, 59.900-000, antoniodiego @ ufersa.edu.br.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In medicine, for example, they can be applied to the following areas: identifying tumors [2]; assisting techniques in the further development of dental treatments [3], etc. Such images are not always achieved with an appropriate quality, and in order to detect the desired information, various methods have been developed to eliminate most of the noise contained in these images. Another problem in image processing is the reduction in resolution, which usu-ally aims at reducing the memory requirement [4]. There are several image reduction techniques in the literature, more recently Paternain et. al. [1] constructed reduction operators with weighted average aggregation functions. The proposed method consists of: (1) To reduce a particular image by using a reduction operator, there are several image reduction techniques in the literature, and (3) to analyze the quality of the last image using weighted aggregation functions.

sections.heading: 2 Aggregation Functions
sections.text: Aggregation functions are important mathematical tools for applications in various fields: Information Fuzzy [6]; Decision Making [9, 8, 7, 11, 10]; Image Processing [1, 2, 12] and Engineering [13]. In this section we present them along with examples and properties. We also introduce a special family of aggregation functions called Ordered Weighted Averaging - OWA and show some of their features.

sections.heading: 2.1 Definition and Examples
sections.text: Aggregation functions associate each entry x with n arguments in the closed interval [0, 1] an output value also in the interval [0, 1]; formally we have: Definition 1. A n-ary aggregation function is a figure f: [0, 1] n → [0, 1], which associates each n-dimensional vector x with a single value f (x) in the interval [0, 1] such that: 1. f (0,..., 0) = 0 and f (1,..., 1) = 1; 2. If x ≤ y, i.e. xi ≤ yi, for all i = 1, 2,..., n, then f (x) ≤ f (y).Example 1. sections.heading: 2.2 Special Types Aggregation Functions
sections.text: An aggregation function f: (1) is ideal if, and only if, f (x,..., x) = x for all x functions [0, 1]. (2) is homogeneous of order k if, and only if, for all x functions [0, 1] and x functions [0, 1] n, f (λx1, 2,..., λxn) = kf (x1, x2,..., xn). If f is homogeneous of order 1, let's just say that f is homogeneous. (3) is shift invariant if, and only, f (x1 + r, x2 + r,..., ≤ etn) = f (x1, x2,.., xn), for all x elements is homogeneous.

sections.heading: 2.3 Ordered Weighted Averaging Function - OWA
sections.text: In the field of aggregation functions, there is a very important subclass in which the elements are parametric (WA) (WA); they are called: Ordered Weighted Averaging or simply OWA [5]. An OWA is an aggregation function that associates weights with all components xi of an input vector x. sections.heading: 4 DY OWA’s as images reduction tools
sections.text: In this part of our work we use the functions DY OWA examined in Examples 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8, and Definition 5 to build image reduction operators, the resulting images are compared with the reduced image used by the operator function H.An image is a matrix m · n 0.5, M = A (i, j) WA, where each A (i, j) represents one pixel. Essentially, a reduction operator reduces a particular image m · n to another m ′ × n ′, so that m ′ < m and n ′ < n. "For example, 0.1 0.2 0 0.5 0.3 0.3 0.2 0.8 1 0.8 1 0.6 0.3 0.5 0.7 − 7 0 1 0.6 In Grayscale images the value of pixels belongs to the set [0, 255] which we can normalize by dividing them by 255 so that we can think of pixels as values in the range.

sections.heading: 5 DY OWA’s as Tools of Noise Reduction
sections.text: In this section, we show that the DY-OWA operators examined in Section III can be used to deal with noise-containing images; the methodology used here is to analyze the previous images with Gaussian noise σ = 10% and 15%; to apply a filter based on the operators H, cOWA and Arith, based on the folding method (see [4]); and to compare the resulting images with the original. Tables III and IV show the power of H on noise images. All the operators listed significantly improved the quality of the image with noise. However, H outperformed all other analyses. Figure 4 shows an example of an image with Gaussian noise σ = 15% and Figure 5 shows the output image after applying the filter of folding with H.The reader can see in Tables III and IV that H proved to be an excellent operator for noise reduction.

sections.heading: 6 Final Remarks
sections.text: In this paper, we propose a generalized form of the ordered weighted averaging function, called the Dynamic Ordered Weighted Averaging function, or simply DYOWA. These functions are defined by weights dynamically obtained from each input vector x [0, 1] n. We show, among other things, that OWA functions are instances of DY OWA, and therefore functions such as: arithmetic method, median, maximum, minimum, and cOWA are also examples of DY OWA. In the second part of this paper, we present a specific DY OWA, called H, and show that it is ideal, symmetrical, homogeneous, shift-invariant, and furthermore has no zero divisors and no neutral elements. Since aggregation functions that satisfy these characteristics are widely used in image processing, we have tested their usefulness: (1) reduce the size of the images and an image reduction (2), resulting in a reduction in noise while increasing.

The proposed method consists of: (1) To reduce a given image by using a reduction operator; (2) To build a new image from the reduced one, and (3) To analyze the quality of the last image by using the measures PSNR and MSIM [4].
They generalize the OWA function introduced by Yager [5] and in particular the operators: Arithmetic Mean, Median, Maximum, Minimum and cOWA.

In fact, if we apply any other function, we get a new image (usually different from the previous one), but what is the best? One possible answer to this question involves a method called magnification or extension (see [19, 20, 21]), which is a method which magnifies the reduced image to another with the same size of the original one.

The methodology employed here consists to analyze the previous images with Gaussian noise σ = 10% and 15%; apply a filter built upon the operators H, cOWA and Arith based on convolution method (See [4]), and compare the resulting images with the original one using PSNR.

This generalization will be developed in such way that the weight vectors are variables depending on the input vector. Particularly, this operators generalize the aggregation functions: Minimum, Maximum, Arithmetic Mean, Median etc, which are extensively used in image processing.
